100k edition: The Isotope Browser goes open source on GitHub

GUIDE
Input:
Element: symbol or Z (c or 6)
Nuclide: 12c, c12, 12 c, c 12, 12-c, c-12
Entire database : *

Change language going to Menu -> Preferences

Element shows the Elements table

Tap an item in the result list to get detailed information
The Database includes ground states and isomers having half-life > 100 ns

Chart
Shows the selected nuclides on the Nuclides Chart. All nuclides are shown when no query is active
The color represents the main decay mode
Zoom to get nuclide names, more to get summary data
Tap to go to the detail page
The Decay chain is shown by a long press on a nuclide. It includes all ground state decay modes having a branching ratio value, and all the possible parents. Use the Preferences to show only the daughters
Spontaneous fission and branching ratios marked as "?" are not drawn
Long press on the same nuclide to reset the chart
Dashed lines represent secondary decay modes.

Expert Search
When the Expert panel is visible, press Go to start searching.
When the panel is hidden its parameters do NOT affect the query

Radiation filter : when a decay radiation type is selected, the result list displays, instead of the decay mode, the most intense line within the selected energy range.
Buttons at the top allow switching between the two display modes. The nuclide detail page will show in red the radiations matching the filter.

When a nuclide symbol entered, a checkbox allows to extend the search of the emitted radiation to the entire decay chain

Result list
Default sorting is by z, n. Use the Preferences to change it. Tap an item to go to the detail page. When a radiation type is selected, two buttons at the top of the list allow to switch the display between radiation intensity + energy and half-life + decay mode

Uncertainties
Are between brackets, and refer to the last significant digit(s):
12.34 (123) means 12.34 +- 1.23

Detail page
Z, N
Number of protons and neutrons, respectively

J\u03C0
Total angular momentum and parity. The value is between brackets when the attribution is not certain

Abundance
Isotope abundance as mole-fraction : fractions of atoms of the isotope in its element

Half-life or Width
Expectation value of the time interval over which half of the atoms originally present in a sample of a given radionuclide would undergo radioactive decay.
For short-lived resonances, the width \u0393 is given. The relationship between Half-life and width comes from the uncertainty principle:
T1/2(s) ≅ ℏ x ln2 / Γ = 4.562 10-22/Γ(MeV)

Parents
Possible parent nuclides. Click on the parent symbol to follow the decay chain upwards

Decay Modes
Tap on decay chain to see it on the chart
Tap on the parent or the daughter symbol to follow the decay chain upwards or downwards, respectively
Note on percentage normalization:
ec \u03b2+ 100\u0025 \u03b2+ p 23\u0025
means that all decays are ec \u03b2+, and 23\u0025 decay by delayed p after \u03b2+

Decay Radiations
For each decay mode, radiation lines having intensity > 1\u0025 of the most intense line - for each radiation type - are listed.
Exception for the above rule, Auger and Conversion electron are included when having an absolute intensity of > 1\u0025.

For beta radiation the mean energy is reported, as well as the decay energy. The decay energy is displayed between brackets when it is calculated. Horizontal scrolling is enabled when the table is large.

Photons emitted by the daughter are included. The intensity of the 511 keV annihilation radiation is listed separately;

Use the Preferences to change the sorting from intensity to energy. See the Expert Search section above on how to set the Radiation Filter mode

Q values
Energy available for the decay of the ground state

Sn and Sp
Neutron and proton separation energy

Magnetic moment
Magnetic dipole moment, expressed in nuclear magnetons

Electric moment
Electric quadrupole moment, expressed in barns

Binding/A
Binding energy per nucleon, in keV

Thermal neutron cross section
Cross section for capturing a neutron with kinetic energy of ~0.025 eV

Resonance Integral
Integral of the neutron absorption reaction rate over the resonance energy region (0.5 eV - \u221E), in barn

Westcott g-factor
The ratio of √π/2 \u00D7 Maxwellian-averaged neutron cross section to the 2200 m/s (thermal 0.0253 eV) cross section

As a side note, C.H. Westcott joined the IAEA in 1963 and established the Nuclear Data Section

Charge radius
Root mean square of the charge radius, expressed in fm.
For the Neutron the mean square value is given, expressed in fm2

Cumulative thermal neutron fission yields
Total number of atoms of each fission product produced over all time after one fission caused by a thermal-energy neutron

Visit us IAEA Nuclear Data Section


Data Sources
Main
Evaluated Nuclear Structure Data Files. The ENSDF is maintained by the International Nuclear Structure and Decay Data network under the auspices of the IAEA.
Q-values, Atomic Masses, and Separation Energies
Atomic Mass Evaluation 2020
Abundances
Nubase 2020
Thermal Neutron Cross Sections
S.F. Mughabghab, Atlas of Neutron Resonances Elsevier Science, 6th Edition, Februay 15 2018, as presented in the Livechart
N.E. Holden in Handbook of Chemistry and Physics 99Th Edition;
I. Dillmann, R. Plag, F. Käppeler and T. Rauscher in KADoNiS v0.3;
J. Kopecky in UKAEA-R(15)30.
Westcott g-factor
Mughabgahb INDC-NDS-0440
Charge Radii
I. Angeli, K. Marinova ADNDT 99 (2013)
Thermal neutron FY
Joint Evaluated Fission and Fusion File JEFF 3.1.1
